Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Representative Bureaucracy and Improving Health Care for Female Veterans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research explores how the values of front-line health care providers in the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) affect the delivery of health care to female veterans. The VA recently required that all of its medical facilities expand health care services to female veterans and simultaneously provide a more private environment for women seeking care in its hospitals and clinics. Compliance is uneven across the 140+ VA medical facilities in the United States and this project explores the impact that female physicians have on moving their facilities towards compliance.

The objective of the project is to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the conditions under which female physicians use their discretion to implement policy to improve the health care experiences of female veterans. The PI will conduct interviews of Veterans Health Administration employees in two select facilities to gauge their attitudes toward compliance, their commitment to the policy, and their efforts to better serve the most quickly growing segment of the VA's clientele. The PI expects that female physicians who identify with female veterans will do the most to improve the quality of care for these women.

Intellectual Merit: Although scholarship suggests that female bureaucrats are more likely than their male colleagues to deliver policy benefits to women in the population, virtually no research directly engages or interviews these women to reach such conclusions. This project forges new ground by interviewing front-line health care providers to gauge their efforts to improve the health care experiences of female veterans. It employs a new theoretical construct for better understanding the ways in which gender shapes the implementation of public policy. The proposed interviews will greatly expand our understanding of the role women play in delivering public policy that benefits women.

Broader Impacts: As a Research in Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) project, the research provides training opportunities for students. The project also has policy implications; the findings may inform the VA about ways to improve the health care experience for female veterans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explores how front-line health care providers in the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) affect the delivery of health care to female veterans. The VA requires that all of its medical facilities provide comprehensive health care to its male as well as female veterans, yet the vast majority of its patients are male. As the largest public health bureaucracy in the country that has historically focused on men's health, scaling up the scope and quality of care for female veterans has come slowly and somewhat unevenly across the 150+ VA medical facilities. Existing research pays scant attention to the role that front-line health care workers play in shaping the health care experiences of male and female veterans. This project fills this gap by exploring how factors such as physician gender and commitment to the VA mission intersect to shape the practice of delivering care to American veterans.

From 2013 to 2018, the PI conducted in-person interviews with physicians employed at four different medical facilities operated by the Department of Veterans Affairs. Physicians were asked a number of open-ended questions about their clinical, teaching, and research responsibilities at the VA, the challenges and rewards of working with the veteran population, their impressions about what the VA does particularly well and what it could do better. In answering these questions, the majority of physicians demonstrated great attentiveness to their patients' needs, male and female, and also suggested areas where the VA could improve. Talking to these physicians made clear their deep commitment to the VA?s mission to "honor America's Veterans by providing exceptional health care that improves their health and well-being."

Similarly, the majority of physicians were attentive to the growing population of female patients seeking care in their facilities and often cognizant of their gender specific needs. Yet despite similar commitment to serving their patients, some notable gender differences emerged. First, compared to their male colleagues, female physicians were considerably more likely to acknowledge and discuss the challenges in providing quality health care to women. Second, only female physicians shared stories and examples about particular women they had treated and focused disproportionately on female patients when sharing anecdotes about serving veterans. Finally, female physicians were also more likely to offer, unsolicited, that they sometimes went the extra mile to ensure women received the care they needed.

In sum, this project expands our understanding of the role physicians play in delivering medical care to the growing population of female veterans. I find that physicians' level of commitment to implementing new policy tailored to female veterans is a function of their gender consciousness, or the extent to which they identify with women. Lack of gender consciousness does not preclude physicians from striving to improve the quality of care for female veterans but identifying with women increases their likelihood of doing so. Female physicians, on the whole, are more gender conscious than male physicians, more likely to recognize women's needs and press for outcomes that benefit women compared to physicians who do not identify strongly with women. As the population of female veterans is expected to reach 10% by 2020, these findings provide important information for VA administrators seeking to improve the quality of care for female veterans in their facilities.
